document.title: New Jersey Student Learning Standards English Language Arts (NJSLS-ELA)

D15658D400F24739848F7F09744A56DB.description:
Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and
situations where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small-group discussion); use formal English
when appropriate to task and situation.

F1BC77E644EA41DFBE9B664869C61CBC.description:
Add audio recordings and visual displays to presentations when appropriate to enhance the
development of main ideas or themes.

CA2B563C84AD4995988AB1979CF578D5.description:
Report on a topic or text, tell a story, or recount an experience in an organized manner, using
appropriate facts and relevant, descriptive details to support main ideas or themes; speak clearly at an
understandable pace.

E78090027E6343D482B249C83B37BE54.description: Identify the reasons and evidence a speaker provides to support particular points.

873406603B5445C59F48AEEB3CF55B9B.description:
Paraphrase portions of a text read aloud or information presented in diverse media and formats
(e.g., visually, quantitatively, and orally).

DA0DDF4CF2FC4E53A45407E9E6ABBD83.description:
Review the key ideas expressed and explain their own ideas and understanding in light of the
discussion.

50646D247A934990BECAE5F762AC44A7.description:
Pose and respond to specific questions to clarify or follow up on information, and make
comments that contribute to the discussion and link to the remarks of others.

9A9E1886D4604DEFA908450614620189.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions and carry out assigned roles.

43F6993DDA5847BD8571A6A4E9C7BF15.description:
Explicitly draw on previously read text or material and other information known about the
topic to explore ideas under discussion.

4B52F708D70D4E9996A94BDC6A3F6916.description:
Engage effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one-on-one, in groups, and
teacher-led) with diverse partners on grade 4 topics and texts, building on others’ ideas and expressing
their own clearly.

85161B62A8C1416B922457AD16FE656B.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (with time for research and revision) and shorter
time frames (a single sitting) for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

CF8919AEFB6F418486EFE377D18AC11E.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources; take notes, prioritize and
categorize information; provide a list of sources.

9B706732F8A141A59D756B96A73C36FB.description:
Conduct short research projects that use multiple reference sources (print and non-print) and
build knowledge through investigation of different aspects of a topic.

07829CAA87F8412E89D9D5D789FBED29.description:
After initial drafting, expand, combine, and reduce sentences for meaning, audience, and
style.

AE075904E02D45E1857BCAF3245EAA43.description:
With adult and peer feedback, and digital or print tools such as a dictionary, thesaurus,
and/or spell checker, evaluate whether the writing achieved its goal and make changes in
content or form as necessary.

7FC8CE4EB00C417D855BF76C046DE9E8.description: Consider writing as a process, including self-evaluation, revision and editing.

E6D1D68ABA9549718D93B666ECD256C2.description:
Use specialized, topic-specific language appropriate for the audience, purpose and subject
matter.

8AAF6965B19349F8A522880ADCCD0AEC.description: Identify audience, purpose, and intended length of composition before writing.

35260F75BCF04499B3ED509746BC6D06.description:
With guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed
by planning, revising, and editing.

FD3A53BBC54C4C33914CA00C15AB3E8C.description: Provide a conclusion that follows from the narrated experiences or events.

5F9A6C9534DC4A1098D098C0D181492C.description:
Use concrete words, phrases, and sensory details and explore using figurative language to
convey experiences and events precisely.

8C20E3C274154E7F999306D796A16EE3.description: Use a variety of transitional words and phrases to manage the sequence of events.

D51AFE7DB9574A669E703ADD5160ECF7.description:
Use dialogue and description to develop experiences and events or show the responses of
characters to situations.

40133A71343641F7821AC70770D8B841.description:
Orient the reader by establishing a situation and introducing a narrator and/or characters;
organize an event sequence that unfolds naturally.

C45CBB4B9C6B4C44B3DB44E2BC8CBCD3.description:
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using narrative technique,
descriptive details, and clear event sequences.

D8E2AAF2D7F147E6BB6186207AF31A2C.description: Provide a conclusion related to the information or explanation presented.

3BDD5515B3904B9B9CFA0A084C9D7B55.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.

D91A83E74C984DE8A1AE132ED0B21103.description:
Link ideas within paragraphs and sections of information using words and phrases (e.g.,
another, for example, also, because).

C4078679178941859339DDDA04240E63.description:
Develop the topic with facts, definitions, concrete details, text evidence, or other
information and examples related to the topic.

168C4A18DB3943B69B931401FF373C6F.description:
Introduce a topic clearly and group related information in paragraphs and sections; include
formatting (e.g., headings), text features (e.g., illustrations, diagrams, captions) and
multimedia when useful to aid in comprehension.

DAF079F1BE4B41E1A875A28EA444A257.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information
clearly.

D99A7364C4D5487A8E6468A21D066E9E.description: Provide a conclusion related to the opinion presented.

ED329935799B41CFA571D371BA849304.description:
Link opinion and reasons using words and phrases (e.g., for instance, in order to, in
addition).

48CEDE09ED124F18B6D196C15FEA803D.description: Provide reasons that are supported by facts from texts and/or other sources.

BD0D1755F4C3443A9777489E39B67EAC.description:
Introduce a topic or text clearly, state an opinion, and create an organizational structure in
which related ideas are grouped to support the writer’s purpose.

CC7EE3870DE4454EAFF36611604F4ED0.description:
Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and
information.

CDD5981193564FCFBB61B2956C0B42E2.description:
Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes, topics and patterns of events in
informational texts from authors of different cultures.

C06BC66918FF43D4B0A00C5D00BB451D.description:
Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes, topics and patterns of events in
literary texts from authors of different cultures.

6E4CB1A0C8BD471EB6BF337A8E384A9F.description:
Analyze how an author uses facts, details and explanations to develop ideas or to support
their reasoning.

2C03F2FC486D4CE6A013D537CDC4A3C8.description:
Use evidence to show how graphics and visuals (e.g., illustrations, charts, graphs, diagrams,
timelines, animations) support central ideas.

37315BD3D1FA44439A5B7F998349C742.description:
Make connections between specific descriptions and directions in a text and a visual or oral
representation of the text.

7471CEF27E114515850507D8846087DA.description:
Compare and contrast multiple accounts of the same event or topic; noting important
similarities and differences in in the point of view they represent.

227959FB06E544BCBE2869818A739A12.description:
Compare and contrast the point of view from which different stories are narrated, including
the difference between first- and third-person narrations.

9B9ECC2240324F1EAB88892A2B9C45C6.description:
Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of
events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.

2C1D1467A4C54EDB993BAD9BB9605581.description:
Explain major differences between poems, drama, and prose, and refer to the structural
elements of poems (e.g., verse, rhythm, meter) and drama (e.g., casts of characters, settings,
descriptions, dialogue, stage directions) when writing or speaking about a text.

936EF5C8860D49BBADE4E093AC17078E.description:
Describe the impact of individuals and events throughout the course of a text, explaining
events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what
happened and why, based on evidence in the text.

4F353817AC1C4C008C931B86BF3E2CBA.description:
Describe the impact of individuals and events throughout the course of a text, using an
in-depth analysis of the character, setting, or event that draws on textual evidence.

FCB400A3A1E848C6AC1E53B5978C9AEA.description:
Summarize an informational text and interpret the author’s purpose or main idea citing key
details from the text.

EA7FE1E204C74100A103490525413B28.description: Summarize a literary text and interpret the author’s theme citing key details from the text.

2083824CFF394533846AB0A16AD5831E.description:
Refer to details and examples as textual evidence when explaining what an informational text
says explicitly and make relevant connections when drawing inferences from the text.

421944730BE74A28B2BE13D157D33F6F.description:
Refer to details and examples as textual evidence when explaining what a literary text says
explicitly and make relevant connections when drawing inferences from the text.

0D3D97F76DA847C1B4235C1961DD8D23.description:
Demonstrate understanding of words by relating them to their opposites (antonyms) and to
words with similar but not identical meanings (synonyms).

66C66C87ECBA45AFBB28ABECF5E25E8C.description: Recognize and explain the meaning of common idioms, adages, and proverbs.

56F1201C8983497D8DF128E084E0FB24.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases that allude to significant characters found in
literature.

9DF335DEDDE2407F9BC5489045C78FD0.description: Explain the meaning of simple similes and metaphors (e.g., as pretty as a picture) in context

127476948B56429EAE6D73F7B4D377A6.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word
meanings.

EDFE3E86A0F049BBAC7A0FDEF05F4F4E.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and
digital, to find the pronunciation and determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words
and phrases.

21071900437A45C4BD611FE10A6B5924.description:
Use common, grade-appropriate Greek and Latin affixes and roots as clues to the meaning of
a word (e.g., telegraph, photograph, autograph).

955D5537B2294A4EB2BA835D036167D3.description:
Use context (e.g., definitions, examples, or restatements in text) as a clue to the meaning of
a word or phrase.

78AB04DA3B7549CA8D76879C5EE5C09E.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning academic and
domain-specific words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range
of strategies.

F6C35B641CE64F66B66C732DA827C6A2.description:
Differentiate between contexts that call for formal English (e.g., presenting ideas) and
situations where informal discourse is appropriate (e.g., small-group discussion).

7876502690DC437F87667A2F67CD9B17.description: Choose words and phrases to convey ideas precisely.

4F3367FFF65447278B637E67BA947B6D.description:
Acquire and use accurately grade-appropriate general academic and domain-specific words
and phrases.

B895D64B7A6249AAB5E2F89EA1D47635.description: Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.

4EE4D1F98ECD476E9E07FC7980E8E404.description:
Use underlining, quotation marks, or italics for titles; use quotation marks for direct speech;
use comma before a coordinating conjunction in a compound sentence.

E5AD1E6C88444307AE18E4DA03AB4002.description:
Capitalize the first word in quotations as appropriate, capitalize other important words (e.g.,
section headings).

2950A9B2F9D54C3AA20A9B4E291EE90B.description: Form and use possessive nouns and pronouns.

DE240CBAA78B40E196D34BD53EA4485B.description: Form irregular verbs; form and use progressive tenses.

EE07AA0A0CB64134971E6D3B4101F4FE.description: Use independent clauses and coordinating conjunctions.

C5CFAE930CA24830BF5B93187D1F806B.description: Place adjectives and adverbs and form comparative and superlative adjectives and adverbs.

A134854A28D147D0A762C11F2CC3FAEA.description:
Use basic paragraphing, including using paragraph indentations and using paragraphs in
dialogue.

8A23A153E2EB4ACCA460FE7F38044571.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of writing, including those listed under grade three
foundational skills:

73F7E0086FEC46E4B586117FCDB424E1.description:
Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and
digital, to find the pronunciation and determine or clarify the precise meaning of key words
and phrases.

8081F135D7F94484B29B840E311F92C3.description: Spell grade-appropriate words correctly, consulting references as needed.

BAB15BA125DF4D6D86EFD5C044721294.description: Write affixed words that involve a sound or spelling change in the base word.

D31E50CDB4184D5480C3AD461FDDF91F.description:
Analyze and spell multi-syllable words with the most common Latin roots, prefixes, and
suffixes.

E6F6E740B89E4DFD8B9E276234D9E50B.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of encoding and spelling.

1C61A3BA6ED3472C82C7A27D9011BE6B.description:
Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, rereading as
necessary.

F2F2060BF16946E4B885A8117AEB67AB.description: Read grade-level text orally with accuracy, appropriate rate, and expression.

8C75575208384DECBC464DDA814D103F.description: Read grade-level text with purpose and understanding.

3C248F812E0A40D8AC325534ED460CAD.description: Read with sufficient accuracy and fluency to support comprehension.
